results.title: [Lasker and Lasker Surf Outfitters: bathing suits and caps: advertisement]
results.brief_description: Promotes Lasker and Lasker Surf Outfitters of 402 and 404 George St, Sydney, N.S.W. Women and men model bathing suits and caps on a beach. Shots include the models standing next to a surf boat, models with parasols, and a model putting on a beach coat. (Cinema advertisement, includes intertitles).

results.title: How to keep a job
results.brief_description: Discusses the habits and attitudes that make for job success once the job is obtained. A man seeking a new job after being fired at his last job is interviewed by the Personnel director of a company and is told that employers want men who are dependable, willing to work, co-operate, loyal and possess initiative.

results.title: The Story of Holmesglen Concrete Housing Project
results.creator_credit: Herschells Films and Housing Commission of Victoria
results.brief_description: The Housing Commission of Victoria has a huge project at Holmesglen, a suburb of Melbourne, for the manufacture of prefabricated houses. All components of a modern house or a block of flats are constructed at this factory and transported in bulk to the place of erection. Concrete walls, chimneys, fences, tiles for roofs, plumbing units, wooden door cupboards and other fittings are all shown under construction and are then shown being fitted into place as the house is erected. Credit is given to the research work being carried out by the CSIRO Building Research Division, particularly in regard to a new type of light weight concrete which has been developed there.

results.title: The High plains
results.creator_credit: Soil Conservation Authority of Victoria and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: The Bogong High Plains contribute to the prosperity of Victoria both as grazing land for cattle and sheep during summer months and as a catchment area for the Kiewa Hydro-Electric Scheme. However, fire, excessive stocking, insect pests and wind have damaged the pastures and soil erosion is now menacing the catchment area. The film outlines methods being used by the Soil Conservation Authority to combat this menace to the State’s hydro-electric projects.

results.title: Hennessy's holiday
results.brief_description: The visit to Melbourne of Hennessy, a 180-pound St. Bernard dog. He sees the Botanical Gardens, the Sidney Myer Music Bowl, and the Shrine, and takes a run around the M.C.G. After intensive grooming he wins a prize at the Royal Melbourne Show, the takes a ride on the “Mightie Mouse” [sic], and he also enjoys a ride on Puffing Billy and a spin on the bay in a speedboat. A modelling appointment, having his portrait drawn by a cartoonist, and an appearance on ‘In Melbourne Tonight’ help make his visit a memorable one for all.

results.title: Heads
results.creator_credit: David Corke, George Dixon and Melbourne Repertory Film Unit
results.brief_description: An experimental film by a group of young Victorian filmmakers. Nonchalantly, the cleaner dusts the works of art created by ancient Greek potters, Renaissance painters and modern sculptors. Each piece marks the stage in our progress as percipient thinking beings: civilisations mature and die - but we survive, at least until today. As the cleaner blows dust from the ear of Epstein’s Einstein, he is ignorant of the terrible forces such a mind has unleashed; for good or ill these forces can, almost, be directed by a toss of a coin.

results.title: The Happy toilers
results.creator_credit: Keith David Smith and Children's Library and Craft Movement
results.brief_description: An amateur record of the efforts by children attending a crafts centre in a migrant hostel to build their own swimming pool. Made at Bradfield Park Housing Settlement and the Lane Cove National Park.

results.title: Half of mankind
results.creator_credit: Ezra Mir, Films Division, Government of India and United Nations
results.brief_description: This film deals with community development in Asia. The village is the unit of organization on which Asia rests, and it is the basis of community development. Three examples are shown: simple self-help in Cambodia; villages cooperating with the World Health Organization to run a health clinic in Afghanistan; interdependence of the agricultural and industrial communities in India, with cash crops providing capital for agricultural development and mechanized expansion of village crafts with the aid of electricity.

results.title: A Half million teenagers
results.brief_description: Studies the physiology aspects of venereal disease. Uses animation to show how the organisms of gonorrhea and syphilis enter and affect the body and how the diseases may be recognised. Stresses the need for treatment, pointing out that there is a cure for both diseases.

results.title: The Gunpowder Man
results.creator_credit: John Richardson and Eastern Suburb's Children's Film Group
results.brief_description:
In this short film, made in 1966, two children build a Guy Fawkes statue, but are spotted by a third child who reveals their secret to their classmates. The children fight over the statue and eventually join forces to light the bonfire together.

The burning of a Guy Fawkes effigy is a tradition that emerged in the UK, initially to commemorate the failure of a plot, known as the Gunpowder Plot, to assassinate King James I in London on 5 November 1605. In its modern form, the tradition is celebrated as more of a social gathering, with a display of bonfires and fireworks. In Australia, it has become less common since the 1970s.

This short film was sponsored by the Eastern Suburbs Children’s Film Group, Melbourne, and produced and directed by John Richardson. Written by John Richardson and Val Fairweather. Featured cast include Christopher Wilson, Scott McClung, Christopher Ely, Robert Bartnik, Ian Mathieson, Daniel Meltzer, Stephen Palamountain and Jamie Steuart.
